abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome and achievement of the
            Agricultural Extension Program Support Project is rated as
            marginally satisfactory. The project registered a series of
            very positive impacts in localized areas throughout the
            country but did not have the widespread productivity
            increases that were envisaged. The lessons drawn from this
            project include: To foster better use of public resources in
            extension services, it is crucial that an extension delivery
            system be demand-driven, responsive to farmer needs,
            results-oriented, accountable to the end beneficiaries
            (farmers), and held accountable when staff performance is
            inadequate. In agricultural services projects, special
            attention to input supply and the marketing aspects of
            agricultural produces is of utmost importance to production
            potential and the conversion of improved production to
            higher farmer income. Partnership system was successful. It
            is recommended that land tenure securization be covered
            through a stand-alone project to magnify the positive
            impacts of a project. The unguided and non-judicious use of
            pesticides results in the build-up of pest resistance and
            provokes environmental degradation. A clear pest management
            policy must be part of project design. Mitigation plans to
            national emergencies should be coupled with a sustainable
            financial mechanism to avoid ad hoc emergency response.
